senses.sense: to stick somewhere, or to make something stick somewhere

senses.sense: to reach someone in front of you by going faster than them

senses.sense: to do something that you did not have time to do earlier

senses.lear_examp: It gave me time to catch up with my reading and sleeping.

senses.sense: compact disc read-only memory: a disc that holds large amounts of information that can be read by a computer but cannot be changed

senses.sense: to stop having or using one thing, and start having or using another

senses.lear_examp: I changed job last month, and now I'm working in a nursery.

senses.sense: to become different, or to make someone or something become different

senses.sense: to take off your clothes and put on different ones

senses.lear_examp: You can change your clothes here.

senses.sense: to take something you have bought back to a store and exchange it for something else

senses.lear_examp: After the first lesson, I changed my mind.

senses.sense: when you stop having or using one thing and start having or using another

senses.sense: an expression of disagreement with ideas, rules, or someone's authority

senses.sense: completely sure of something, or knowing without doubt that something is true

senses.sense: to know something without doubt

senses.sense: a period of 100 years, especially used in giving dates

senses.sense: the start of a new century

senses.sense: an official document that gives details to show that something is true

senses.sense: a formal event that is performed on important social or religious occasions

senses.sense: a state of total confusion with no order

senses.lear_examp: There was chaos at the school.

senses.sense: pleasant and attractive

senses.sense: a quality which makes you like or feel attracted to someone or something

senses.sense: an object that you keep or wear because you believe that it is lucky

senses.sense: to put electricity into something

senses.sense: the amount of money that you have to pay for something, especially for an activity or service

senses.sense: to be the person who has control of or is responsible for someone or something

senses.sense: costing little money or less than is usual or expected

senses.sense: low in price and quality

senses.sense: to run after someone or something in order to catch them

senses.sense: a person represented in a film, play or story

senses.lear_examp: Mary had a strong character and faced her uncle with great courage.

senses.sense: qualities that are interesting or unusual

senses.sense: an interesting or funny person whose behavior is different from most people's

senses.sense: a letter, sign, or number that you use when you are writing or printing

senses.sense: a particular kind of person

senses.sense: a television station

senses.sense: a way of communicating with people or getting something done

senses.lear_examp: Quite a few, it seems, opted to go for places where they had previously worked. 17% from Education, 5% from Arts and Science and 3% from the Science Stream, come under this category.

senses.sense: to experience something, often something unpleasant
senses.dict_examp: We came under a lot of pressure to leave the area.
senses.lear_examp: This opinion is true in a sense but it also depends on how kids are brought up and what influences they came under.

senses.sense: to move toward someone
senses.dict_examp: A young girl came up to me and asked for money.
senses.lear_examp: A tall slim Soc came up and said:- "I will, Daryl old bud." It was James, Daryl's old school friend.

senses.sense: to be mentioned or talked about in conversation
senses.dict_examp: What points came up at the meeting?
senses.lear_examp: From time to time the discussion about keeping animals in zoos comes up.

senses.sense: When the sun or moon comes up, it rises.
senses.dict_examp: We watched the sun come up over the ocean.

senses.sense: If a job or opportunity comes up, it becomes available.
senses.dict_examp: If some work comes up, you should take it.
senses.lear_examp: I am delighted to help and advise you about the three proposals that have just come up.

senses.sense: to be happening soon
senses.dict_examp: Final exams are coming up next month.
senses.lear_examp: A holiday is coming up next month so it would be great if you could come sometime between Wednesday 27th to Saturday 30th.

senses.sense: If a problem or difficult situation comes up, it happens.
senses.dict_examp: Sorry I'm late - a problem came up with my schedule.
senses.lear_examp: I found it very useful that I did not have to write or read, and if a problem came up I just called the qualified teacher.

senses.sense: If information comes up on a computer screen, it appears there.
senses.dict_examp: The images came up on the screen.
senses.lear_examp: The photo instantly comes up on the screen of the computer and you can enjoy the game with the photo.

senses.sense: to have to deal with a problem or difficulty
senses.dict_examp: She came up against a lot of sexism in her first engineering job.
senses.lear_examp: It is essential to get along well with your partners, otherwise you may come up against many problems, such as a loss of motivation, or even the risk of being fired.

senses.sense: to suggest or think of an idea or plan
senses.dict_examp: She's come up with some amazing scheme to double her income.
senses.lear_examp: Together with my teacher we came up with the idea of asking you to come to the college in order to give a talk about your latest book and about the experiences you have had as a novelist.

senses.sense: an officer who is in charge of a military operation, or an officer of middle rank in the navy
senses.dict_examp: He was a naval commander.
senses.lear_examp: The best part is when the commander forces the troops to kill themselves to prove their loyalty.

senses.sense: someone who entertains people by telling jokes
senses.lear_examp: Then, he went to London to become a comedian and now he is one of the most famous stars in that field.

senses.sense: something that you say or write that expresses your opinion
senses.dict_examp: I don't want any comments about my new haircut!
senses.lear_examp: Write me a comment.

senses.sense: used to say that you do not want to answer someone's question
senses.dict_examp: "Will you be running for Congress?" "No comment."

senses.sense: to make a comment
senses.dict_examp: My mom always comments on what I'm wearing.
senses.lear_examp: I will only comment on some points, the others may be viewed as agreed upon.

senses.sense: the activities involved in buying and selling things
senses.dict_examp: the world of commerce and industry
senses.lear_examp: In the old days, when the only means of transport were horses, there were many difficulties in communication between people, in commerce, and in life generally.

senses.sense: a mark (,) used to separate parts of a sentence, or to separate the items in a list
senses.dict_examp: Put a comma before his name.

senses.sense: in a comfortable way
senses.dict_examp: We slept very comfortably that night.
senses.lear_examp: I was sitting comfortably on the couch watching TV when suddenly all the lights went out, and everything became silent.

senses.sense: a magazine with stories told in pictures
senses.dict_examp: As a boy I used to love reading comics.
senses.lear_examp: My hobbies are playing basketball and reading comics.

senses.sense: funny
senses.dict_examp: a comic actor/performance
senses.lear_examp: I think it's a bit long for a comic film (3 hours!!) but it's very funny: you must see it.

senses.sense: entertainment such as a film, play, etc. which is funny
senses.dict_examp: His latest film is described as a romantic comedy.
senses.lear_examp: Everybody agreed to see that comedy with Jim Carrey and I know that you would like it.

senses.sense: when you are willing to give your time and energy to something that you believe in, or a promise or firm decision to do something
senses.dict_examp: She is known primarily for her commitment to human rights.
senses.lear_examp: I really admire your stamina, your commitment and your eagerness to pursue a career as one of the youngest vice presidents ever in the company (and the only female I guess), but is it really worth it?

senses.sense: something that you must do or deal with that takes your time
senses.dict_examp: family/work commitments
senses.lear_examp: Please tell me also the terms of the possible job so I can plan my future work commitments.

senses.sense: to share information with others by speaking, writing, moving your body or using other signals
senses.dict_examp: We can now communicate instantly with people on the other side of the world.
senses.lear_examp: Finally, I decided to join a new English class in order to improve my English because a few weeks ago I met someone who is really interesting, so I would like to be able to communicate properly with him.

senses.sense: to be understood by someone when you tell them about your feelings and thoughts
senses.dict_examp: He can't communicate with his parents.
senses.lear_examp: I think I can communicate with children and make them happy.

senses.sense: to take part in a race or competition
senses.dict_examp: She's competing for a spot on next year's Olympic team.
senses.lear_examp: There's gonna be a competition and I want to compete, but you know that my bicycle is a mess and very old.

senses.sense: to try to be more successful than someone or something else
senses.dict_examp: It's difficult for a small grocery store to compete against/with the big supermarkets.
senses.lear_examp: She had to compete with twelve other writers.

senses.sense: an organization that sells goods or services in order to make money
senses.dict_examp: He works for a software company/a company that makes software.
senses.lear_examp: Nokia is a famous company as you know.

senses.sense: when you are with a person or people, or the person or people you are with
senses.dict_examp: I just enjoy his company.
senses.lear_examp: Fortunately a friend of mine came with me for company.

senses.sense: to stay with someone so that they are not alone
senses.dict_examp: Come and keep me company, Isabel.
senses.lear_examp: Usually I went with him to keep him company and because I liked it.

senses.sense: to be a pleasant or interesting person to spend time with
senses.dict_examp: Ann and Charles are always good company.
senses.lear_examp: He is a bit narrow-minded and at first he'll drive you crazy, but once you get to know him he'll be good company.

senses.sense: an organized event in which people try to win a prize by being the best, fastest, etc.
senses.dict_examp: a swimming/chess competition
senses.lear_examp: I'm in Australia. I have just seen a surf competition that was very exciting.

senses.sense: when someone, or a company, is trying to win something or be more successful than someone else
senses.dict_examp: Competition for jobs is intense.
senses.lear_examp: Different opening times means competition between the shops.

senses.sense: to examine the ways in which two people or things are different
senses.dict_examp: If you compare house prices in the two areas, it's surprising how different they are.
senses.lear_examp: Our lives are so different, it's interesting to compare.

senses.sense: used when saying how one person or thing is different from another
senses.dict_examp: This street is very busy compared to ours.
senses.lear_examp: To my surprise it was very cheap compared with other restaurants.

senses.sense: If two people compare notes, they tell each other what they think about something that they have both done.
senses.dict_examp: We compared notes about our experiences in China.
senses.lear_examp: In conclusion, regular meetings between parents and school teachers ... help both parties to compare notes, acting in the best interests of the children.

senses.sense: the form of an adjective or adverb that expresses a difference in amount, in number, in degree or quality
senses.dict_examp: "Fatter" is the comparative of "fat."

senses.sense: comparing similar things
senses.dict_examp: a comparative study of two poems
senses.lear_examp: In a comparative study we see the work force is increasing in Japan, whereas it is declining in U.S.

senses.sense: a situation which is comfortable/free/silent, etc. when compared to another situation or to what is usual
senses.dict_examp: I enjoyed the comparative calm of his apartment after the busy office.
senses.lear_examp: Uruguay has exploited its comparative advantages orienting its economy towards tourism, whereas Argentina has made use of the river to promote the export of domestic products.

senses.sense: compatible equipment can be used together
senses.dict_examp: This keyboard is compatible with all of our computers.
senses.lear_examp: Actually it is compatible with the newest 3DFX technology, which gives an extremely realistic look and the possibility to interact with the game.

senses.sense: If people are compatible, they like each other and are happy to spend time together.
senses.dict_examp: After they got married, they soon found out that they weren't compatible.
senses.lear_examp: The personalities of my parents were very different but at the same time they were a very compatible couple.

senses.sense: compatible ideas or situations can exist together
senses.dict_examp: Such policies are not compatible with democratic government.
senses.lear_examp: My aim here is not to criticize this point of view but to show it is hardly compatible with the idea of giving work less importance.

senses.sense: to pay someone money because you are responsible for injuring them or damaging something
senses.dict_examp: Victims of the crash will be compensated for their injuries.
senses.lear_examp: I would like to be compensated for the extra work I have done to please the guests from the last stay.

senses.sense: to reduce the bad effect of something, or make something bad become something good
senses.dict_examp: Nothing will ever compensate for his lost childhood.
senses.lear_examp: Yet, it seems obvious that money cannot compensate for a lack of affection.

senses.sense: the act of communicating with people
senses.dict_examp: Television is an increasingly important means of communication.
senses.lear_examp: Communication by e-mail is very fast and very cheap.

senses.sense: often or usually
senses.dict_examp: These caterpillars are commonly found on bean plants.
senses.lear_examp: For example, fast food and microwave food are commonly eaten by the British.

senses.sense: an advertisement on the radio, on television, etc.
senses.dict_examp: I turn the sound  off during the commercials.
senses.lear_examp: I don't watch tv because of the commercials.

senses.sense: related to buying and selling things
senses.dict_examp: a commercial organization/success
senses.lear_examp: Unfortunately, as long as their private life is interesting for ordinary people and it brings commercial gain to publishers, journalists and photographers, famous people will just have to get used to this living "under a microscope".

senses.sense: making money from advertising
senses.dict_examp: commercial television
senses.lear_examp: These days, in all commercial television, they show advertisements in every hour of the day.

senses.sense: cheap/easy/little, etc. when compared to something else or to what is usual
senses.dict_examp: The climb was comparatively easy.
senses.lear_examp: Although I am not a professional interpreter, please notice that my earnings are comparatively low.

senses.sense: open and willing to talk to people
senses.dict_examp: She's never very communicative in the morning.
senses.lear_examp: First of all, I would like to say I am a very communicative person and I enjoy being surrounded by many people.

senses.sense: involving competition
senses.dict_examp: competitive sports
senses.lear_examp: Nowadays people live in a very competitive society.

senses.sense: wanting very much to win or be more successful than other people
senses.dict_examp: She's very competitive.
senses.lear_examp: I think that I am a very competitive player.

senses.sense: as good as or better than other prices, services, etc.
senses.dict_examp: They offer high quality merchandise at competitive prices.
senses.lear_examp: I stayed at Riverside Hotel which is great value because of the food and the competitive prices they offer.

senses.sense: the people living in one particular area
senses.dict_examp: a rural/small community
senses.lear_examp: He supported some projects in our community.

senses.sense: a group of people with the same interests, way of life, nationality, job, etc.
senses.dict_examp: the black/white/Chinese/Jewish community
senses.lear_examp: As a member of our academic community, and a representative of the student's senate, I'm very glad to hear that our college will have a surplus in its annual budget.

senses.sense: loyal and willing to give your time and energy to something that you believe in
senses.dict_examp: a committed marathon runner
senses.lear_examp: All in all, Mr. Schmidt is a very committed and hard-working person.

senses.sense: when two or more people or things are compared
senses.dict_examp: They made a comparison of different countries' eating habits.
senses.lear_examp: Nowadays we can see a very different world from the one our grandparents were living in. Whereas they used to talk about how their daily life had changed in comparison with previous generations', we remain astonished at  how our lives are changing frenetically.

senses.sense: able to do something well
senses.dict_examp: a competent teacher/swimmer
senses.lear_examp: As the game develops, the creatures and tasks get more and more complicated and by the end of the game, you will be expected to become a competent shooter.

senses.sense: happening often or existing in large numbers
senses.dict_examp: It's quite common to see couples who dress alike.
senses.lear_examp: The city is so noisy and it's possible that you will get lost, it's very common.

senses.sense: belonging to or shared by two or more people or things
senses.dict_examp: a common goal/interest
senses.lear_examp: I invited her to dinner for all her trouble and we found out that we have a lot of common interests.

senses.sense: something that a lot of people know
senses.dict_examp: It's common knowledge that he spent time in jail.
senses.lear_examp: It is common knowledge that such attention in the mass-media inevitably tells on relationships in the family.

senses.sense: to share, interests, experiences, or other characteristics with someone or something
senses.dict_examp: Sue and I don't have much in common.
senses.lear_examp: We both like to read fantasy books so we have a lot in common.

senses.sense: to do something that is considered wrong, or that is illegal
senses.dict_examp: He was sent to prison for a crime that he didn't commit.
senses.lear_examp: She is willing to be a witness for the prosecution and states that her husband was not with her at the time the crime was committed.

senses.sense: to make a firm decision that you will do something
senses.dict_examp: He committed himself to helping others.
senses.lear_examp: Doctor Gregorio Alvarez was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina in the early 1910s and graduated as a doctor at an early age. ... He worked his entire life in the public hospital in Neuquen, which was the most developed city at that time, but he committed himself to exploration on a permanent basis.

senses.sense: to regularly travel between work and home
senses.dict_examp: He commutes to Boston every day.
senses.lear_examp: People who work in the city center will have to commute from the suburbs which will be a waste of time for them.

senses.sense: someone you spend a lot of time with or go somewhere with
senses.dict_examp: a traveling companion
senses.lear_examp: Jane and her companion felt absolutely foolish and muttered something about a wrong address.

senses.sense: similar in size, amount, or quality to something else
senses.dict_examp: Our prices are comparable to those in other stores.
senses.lear_examp: Recent surveys revealed that the gap in salary between men and women doing comparable jobs increased within the last years.

senses.sense: the ability to do something well

senses.lear_examp: This report aims to outline the present state of our library's archives as well as to recommend another book or newspaper for those interested in improving their competence in Greek.

senses.sense: a product that you can buy or sell
senses.dict_examp: The country's most valuable commodities include tin and diamonds.
senses.lear_examp: Not just that, it will have a domino effect on prime commodities as well.

senses.sense: a small group of people chosen to represent a larger organization and either make decisions or collect information for it
senses.dict_examp: She's on the school's development committee.
senses.lear_examp: I'm pleased to help and to present these films to the club committee.

senses.sense: to feel that you should do something

senses.lear_examp: As a member of the International Student's Sports Club, I felt compelled to write this article in answer to the previous article about how today's youth is putting sports and healthy activities aside.

senses.sense: the natural ability to be practical and to make good decisions
senses.dict_examp: The children shouldn't be in any danger as long as they use their common sense.
senses.lear_examp: In fact she is very nice, funny, and full of common sense.

senses.sense: when something is complex

senses.lear_examp: Will this system of planting and exploiting new values, styles and icons actually collapse under its own weight and complexity?

senses.sense: when someone says that something is wrong or not satisfactory
senses.dict_examp: We've received a complaint from one of our listeners about offensive language.
senses.lear_examp: I hope you give my complaint serious consideration and I would be very pleased if you would print a correction in the next issue of your magazine.

senses.sense: something that makes you complain
senses.dict_examp: My only complaint was the lack of refreshments.
senses.lear_examp: One of their complaints is the absence of variety of options for vegetarians.

senses.sense: to obey an order, rule, or request
senses.dict_examp: The pilot complied with instructions to descend.
senses.lear_examp: To comply with even the highest security standards, WEB-DMS features cutting-edge encryption and access control technologies.

senses.sense: to say that something is wrong or that you are annoyed about something
senses.dict_examp: Lots of people have complained about the noise.
senses.lear_examp: If we are bad, they complain to our manager or they tell the head office.

senses.sense: to tell other people that something is making you feel ill
senses.dict_examp: She's been complaining of a headache all day.
senses.lear_examp: I asked her if he had complained of any pains or aches?

senses.sense: including everything
senses.dict_examp: a comprehensive study of the subject
senses.lear_examp: Presentations on making a career in media, finance and IT could have been more comprehensive.

senses.sense: something which makes a situation more difficult
senses.dict_examp: We want to sign the contract, but there are several complications.
senses.lear_examp: As you have already correctly mentioned in your memorandum, we indeed face some complications in our resort.

senses.sense: a new medical problem that develops when you are already ill
senses.dict_examp: Eye problems can be a complication of diabetes.
senses.lear_examp: Disregarding recommendations given by nutrition experts can pose a great threat to our longevity, namely because of cardio-vascular complications.

senses.sense: involving a lot of different parts, in a way that is difficult to understand
senses.dict_examp: complicated instructions
senses.lear_examp: Life is getting easier but more complicated - I could have written a letter in a bottle but waiting for the answer would take a decade, now it's just a click of a button.

senses.sense: someone who writes music
senses.dict_examp: a famous composer
senses.lear_examp: I would like to participate in the planned lectures about the opera composers of the 18th century.

senses.sense: to collect information and arrange it in a book, report, list, etc.
senses.dict_examp: We're compiling some facts and figures for a documentary on climate change.
senses.lear_examp: The aim of this report is to compile the findings and thereby outline the main reasons why our branch did not get the contract, in order to prevent future failures.

senses.sense: a person, team or company that is competing against others
senses.dict_examp: How many competitors took part in the race?
senses.lear_examp: The last one I saw was called 'Spelling' and it was a kind of quiz where the competitors had to spell difficult words fast and finish at a certain time.

senses.sense: when you agree to something which is not exactly what you want
senses.dict_examp: It is hoped that a compromise will be reached in today's talks.
senses.lear_examp: I hope that we'll find a compromise.

senses.sense: to agree to something that is not exactly what you want
senses.dict_examp: In a relationship, both people have to compromise.
senses.lear_examp: The  famous stars and the journalists should compromise and respect each other's rights.

senses.sense: to have a harmful effect on something
senses.dict_examp: The trial has been seriously compromised by sensational media coverage.
senses.lear_examp: Sportsmen are usually under an enormous amount of pressure, because the slightest failure could compromise their career.

senses.sense: involving competition
senses.dict_examp: competitive sports
senses.lear_examp: Nowadays people live in a very competitive society.

senses.sense: wanting very much to win or be more successful than other people
senses.dict_examp: She's very competitive.
senses.lear_examp: I think that I am a very competitive player.

senses.sense: as good as or better than other prices, services, etc.
senses.dict_examp: They offer high quality merchandise at competitive prices.
senses.lear_examp: I stayed at Riverside Hotel which is great value because of the food and the competitive prices they offer.

senses.sense: involving a lot of different but connected parts in a way that is difficult to understand
senses.dict_examp: a complex network of roads
senses.lear_examp: It took us two weeks to modify the results in a very complex operation.

senses.sense: a group of buildings or rooms that are used for a particular purpose
senses.dict_examp: a sports/housing/apartment complex
senses.lear_examp: A visit to any local shopping complex suggests people between 14 to 35 years of age are the most frequent shoppers.

senses.sense: a mental problem which makes someone anxious or frightened about something
senses.dict_examp: an inferiority complex
senses.lear_examp: He began to feel like that character in "Psycho", afraid that the hotel manager would turn out to be some kind of maniac with an Oedipus complex.

senses.sense: to be the parts that something consists of
senses.dict_examp: The committee was composed of elected leaders and citizens.
senses.lear_examp: It is composed of more than 50 members and they have various tastes in film: old and modern, comedy, action and so on.

senses.sense: to write a piece of music
senses.dict_examp: Who composed the music for the film?
senses.lear_examp: I've been composing music on a computer for over five years and I have a lot of knowledge when it comes to hardware.

senses.sense: to provide the last part needed to make something whole
senses.dict_examp: Complete the sentence with one of the adjectives provided.
senses.lear_examp: I will buy episode III as it is the only one that I need to complete my collection.

senses.sense: to write all the details asked for on a form or other document
senses.dict_examp: Have you completed your application form yet?
senses.lear_examp: Sometimes we complete the forms and talk.

senses.sense: to finish doing or making something
senses.dict_examp: The palace took over twenty years to complete.
senses.lear_examp: I need this paper to complete my grade.

senses.sense: very great or to the largest degree possible
senses.dict_examp: It was a complete waste of time.
senses.lear_examp: It was a complete disaster!

senses.sense: with all the parts
senses.dict_examp: the complete works of Oscar Wilde
senses.lear_examp: I can send you a complete map.

senses.sense: the color and appearance of the skin on someone's face
senses.dict_examp: a clear complexion
senses.lear_examp: She had a fair complexion framed with red hair which reminded me of a witch.

senses.sense: something that you say or do to show praise or admiration for someone
senses.dict_examp: Thank you for the  compliment, but many people helped me along the way.
senses.lear_examp: I take that as a compliment, giving me hope to excel as well as he did.

senses.sense: to tell someone that you admire something about them
senses.dict_examp: He paid her several compliments about her painting.
senses.lear_examp: His companions always pay him compliments on his piano playing.

senses.sense: used by someone to express good wishes when they give you something free, for example in a restaurant
senses.dict_examp: Please accept this champagne with the compliments of the manager.
senses.lear_examp: The guest can also choose from a selection of wonderful desserts such as mousse au chocolat with fresh raspberries before finishing his/her meal with a rose liqueur - with the compliments of the house (and the bill).

senses.sense: to praise or express admiration for someone
senses.dict_examp: He complimented me on my writing.
senses.lear_examp: Firstly, I must compliment you on lowering your prices and adding new destinations to choose from.

senses.sense: A compulsive habit is something that you do a lot because you want to so much that you cannot control yourself.
senses.dict_examp: a compulsive eating disorder
senses.lear_examp: However, the center has a potential to affect shoppers, rendering them more compulsive.

senses.sense: so interesting or exciting that you cannot stop reading, playing, or watching it
senses.dict_examp: This documentary about life in prison makes compulsive viewing.

senses.sense: completely
senses.dict_examp: Sources are comprehensively listed at the back of the book.
senses.lear_examp: However enjoyable and relaxing, driving needs your full attention. Therefore, it should be learned comprehensively and being experienced shouldn't be relied on.

senses.sense: in every way or as much as possible
senses.dict_examp: I completely forgot I'd said I would call him.
senses.lear_examp: In the middle of the journey there was one of those summer rain showers and we got completely wet.

senses.sense: a short piece of writing about a particular subject, done by a student
senses.dict_examp: a 500-word composition
senses.lear_examp: I have to do a composition in English to cover the work I missed.

senses.sense: a piece of music that someone has written
senses.dict_examp: This concerto is one of her later compositions.
senses.lear_examp: He sang Schubert's "Die Winterreise" although it's already Spring - this composition can be heard in every season.

senses.sense: the parts, substances, etc. that something consists of
senses.dict_examp: the composition of the atmosphere
senses.lear_examp: The eating procedure takes approx. 3 hrs, as each course is introduced by a detailed description of its preparation and composition.

senses.sense: the way that people or things are arranged in a painting or photograph
senses.dict_examp: The composition of the painting was perfect.
senses.lear_examp: The study of acting, directing, and generally speaking of the scene has always demanded a certain degree of visual composition, a sense of image and of that which is immediately seen (or not seen).

senses.sense: the process or skill of writing music
senses.dict_examp: He taught composition at Yale.
senses.lear_examp: He finished music composition at the University in Cracow, and he soon became the professor of composition at the same school of music.

senses.sense: to consist of particular parts or members
senses.dict_examp: The orchestra was comprised of amateur and professional musicians.
senses.lear_examp: It comprises only twelve single and six double bedrooms, which will provide the intimacy we need.

senses.sense: to form part of something, especially a larger group
senses.dict_examp: Women comprise 15% of the police force.
senses.lear_examp: According to a survey carried out in 1997, the urban population comprises 71% of the total population in Pakistan.

senses.sense: when something that you are doing or making is finished
senses.dict_examp: The stadium is due for completion in 2016.
senses.lear_examp: After the completion of the work at the newly-built part of the airport and its opening for service, the formerly quiet part of the town has become a victim of the above mentioned kind of noise, even more than the parts which have had this problem for a long time.

senses.sense: one of the parts of a machine or piece of equipment
senses.dict_examp: Our company makes components for aircraft engines.
senses.lear_examp: Since both the hardware and software components used by the employees of this department are not in a good state, there is a need of brand new and more powerful computers and of updated software.

senses.sense: one of the parts or characteristics of something or someone
senses.dict_examp: The course has four distinct components.
senses.lear_examp: These components are present in everyone, whether you are rich or poor, thus it is wrong to be biased with one kind of people purely based on beliefs not supported by solid evidence.

senses.sense: to make something more difficult to deal with or understand
senses.dict_examp: These new regulations just complicate matters further.
senses.lear_examp: My friend, I hope I didn't complicate things for you with my appraisal of the situation.

senses.sense: praising or expressing admiration for someone
senses.dict_examp: a complimentary report

senses.sense: given free, especially by a business
senses.dict_examp: a complimentary glass of wine
senses.lear_examp: It may be easy to obtain complimentary copies from publishers without any cost to the library.

senses.sense: something that you agree to do or give to someone in order to end an argument
senses.dict_examp: Both sides will have to make concessions.
senses.lear_examp: Nevertheless, I still have the impression that some concessions have to be made and from personal experience, I can say it is very different to base your choice on a single criterion.

senses.sense: to think of an idea or plan
senses.dict_examp: The original idea for the novel was conceived in Rome.
senses.lear_examp: I wonder what kind of person conceived this terrible and ignorant idea.

senses.sense: to be able to imagine something
senses.dict_examp: I cannot conceive of anything more horrible.
senses.lear_examp: You cannot conceive of any other way of existence than the one you know.

senses.sense: to become pregnant
senses.dict_examp: She had been trying for years, but never managed to conceive.
senses.lear_examp: By then she had everything she could ask for but for some reason she did not conceive for 2 years. Then she conceived but had two miscarriages.

senses.sense: in a way that proves that something is true
senses.dict_examp: It is possible to prove conclusively that he was at home at the time.
senses.lear_examp: This undeniable fact implies advantages that were unthinkable in the past, yet we cannot prove conclusively that the gains outweigh the losses.

senses.sense: to organize and perform a particular activity
senses.dict_examp: We are conducting a survey to find out what our customers think of their local bus service.
senses.lear_examp: This is based on a questionnaire conducted in the school and our English department's investigation.

senses.sense: to stand in front of a group of musicians and control their performance
senses.dict_examp: The orchestra was conducted by Charles Miller.
senses.lear_examp: The orchestra conducted by Mr Miller was just superb.

senses.sense: to behave in a particular way
senses.dict_examp: She conducted herself with great dignity.
senses.lear_examp: The qualities I admire most in other people are, first of all, the ability to hide your own feelings - being a little reserved - and at the same time the ability to conduct yourself in such a way so that other people are influenced by you.

senses.sense: the particular state that something or someone is in
senses.dict_examp: My bike's a few years old, but it's in really good condition.
senses.lear_examp: It's very beautiful and in good condition.

senses.sense: the physical situation that someone or something is in and affected by
senses.dict_examp: The prisoners were kept in the most appalling conditions.
senses.lear_examp: Although I had fun the weather conditions were horrible - it was raining all the time and the road was too wet to ride on.

senses.sense: an illness
senses.dict_examp: a medical condition
senses.lear_examp: Besides, all the fats we eat every day plus the accumulated stress of a job, makes us the perfect candidates for a heart condition.

senses.sense: only if
senses.dict_examp: I'll come with you on the condition that we're back before midnight.
senses.lear_examp: I would like to do this on condition that you will not mention my name on the website.

senses.sense: something that must happen or be agreed before something else can happen
senses.dict_examp: One of the conditions of the contract is that we can't keep pets.
senses.lear_examp: Now I want you to pay for that as it was agreed between us and according to the terms and conditions of the contract.

senses.sense: to make a person or animal behave in a particular way by influencing the way they think
senses.dict_examp: The boys were conditioned to be aggressive.
senses.lear_examp: Young people are being subconsciously conditioned to become consumers in every sense of the word.

senses.sense: too proud of yourself and your actions
senses.dict_examp: I find him very conceited.
senses.lear_examp: This is not to say that the successful person must be smug, conceited or bumptious; but he has to be convinced of his own skills and abilities.

senses.sense: an electronic machine that can store and arrange large amounts of information
senses.dict_examp: We've put all our records on the computer.
senses.lear_examp: There are lots of books and computers.

senses.sense: the ability to think carefully about something you are doing and nothing else
senses.dict_examp: The noise outside made concentration difficult.
senses.lear_examp: First of all, in my opinion, watching a film is more relaxing, because you don't have to concentrate too much on it. You only have to watch the screen, while books require more concentration.

senses.sense: a large number or amount of something in the same place
senses.dict_examp: high concentrations of minerals
senses.lear_examp: Again, we may need to think about the implementation of more strict regulations related to the concentration of toxic chemicals in exhausts.

senses.sense: to decide something after studying all the information about it very carefully
senses.dict_examp: The report concluded that the drug was safe.
senses.lear_examp: Taking all these reasons into consideration, it can be concluded that there are many advantages & disadvantages of the decision to ban cars in city centers.

senses.sense: to end something such as a meeting, speech, or piece of writing by doing or saying one last thing
senses.dict_examp: The concert concluded with fireworks.
senses.lear_examp: To conclude, I would like to underline one more time how crucial the setting up of a library would be for our college.

senses.sense: an idea about what something is like or a way of understanding something
senses.dict_examp: They have no conception of how ordinary people live.
senses.lear_examp: Therefore, unless we stretch the conception of personality to cover conformity with practice and social norms, economic decisions, and the choice of identities we aspire to, the clothes that people wear may not reflect their personality, as this can be conditioned by many contingencies.

senses.sense: proving that something is true
senses.dict_examp: conclusive evidence/proof
senses.lear_examp: Although there is no conclusive evidence of the influence of food on people's behavior, we can observe certain patterns of behavior depending on what kind of food people eat.

senses.sense: a very hard building material made by mixing together cement, sand, small stones and water
senses.dict_examp: reinforced concrete
senses.lear_examp: Some of our children, brought up in modern cities, in a world of concrete, cars, motorways and supermarkets, when asked: "What is a fish?" are only able to answer: "a square piece of white flesh we take from the freezer".

senses.sense: certain or based on facts
senses.dict_examp: They think she killed her husband, but they have no concrete evidence/proof.
senses.lear_examp: Another piece of concrete evidence to suggest that children from a poorer background cannot cope with social problems properly compared to the other group is the fact that they are more inclined to be the troublemakers themselves.

senses.sense: existing in a real form that can be seen or felt
senses.dict_examp: concrete achievements/actions
senses.lear_examp: In order to turn it into a feasible concept, this process of learning should be applied to concrete situations.

senses.sense: a principle or idea
senses.dict_examp: the concept of free speech
senses.lear_examp: I had been trying very hard to get the point of the concept.

senses.sense: to be important to someone or to involve someone directly
senses.dict_examp: Matters of pollution and the environment concern us all.
senses.lear_examp: Fitness and health are two important issues in life which concern all of us.

senses.sense: to be about a particular subject
senses.dict_examp: The next item on the agenda concerns staffing.
senses.lear_examp: Your other question concerns clothes.

senses.sense: to worry or upset someone
senses.dict_examp: What really concerns me is her lack of experience.
senses.lear_examp: I read your newspaper announcement and because I am seriously concerned I decided to write you this letter.

senses.sense: when you feel worried or nervous about something, or something that makes you feel worried
senses.dict_examp: Concern for the safety of the two missing teenagers is growing.
senses.lear_examp: All those days I put aside all my concerns about my studies.

senses.sense: something that is important to you, or when something is important
senses.dict_examp: Our primary concern is safety.
senses.lear_examp: My concern is what present to buy for Mr Brown.

senses.sense: the opinion you have after considering all the information about something
senses.dict_examp: At first I thought he was being rude, but I've come to/reached the conclusion that he's just shy.
senses.lear_examp: Dear Jack and Ben: I've been thinking about your last letter for quite a long time and I came to the following conclusion.

senses.sense: used to introduce the last part of a speech or a piece of writing
senses.dict_examp: In conclusion, I would like to thank our guest speaker for her fascinating talk.
senses.lear_examp: In conclusion, music, TV and clothes are very important in a young person's life and can reflect each person's character.

senses.sense: to guess the facts about a situation without having all of the information
senses.dict_examp: It’s not fair to jump to conclusions based on one incident.
senses.lear_examp: I think, before jumping to conclusions, we should first try to analyse the situation.

senses.sense: the final part of something
senses.dict_examp: the dramatic conclusion of the movie
senses.lear_examp: When it comes to the crunch, he is patient and persistent enough to carry a project to a successful conclusion.

senses.sense: to cause you to think that something is probably true
senses.dict_examp: So you thought I was leaving, did you?  What led you to that conclusion?
senses.lear_examp: These results lead us to the conclusion that only people with "minds tough enough" will survive.

senses.sense: to say very strongly that you think something is wrong or very bad
senses.dict_examp: The President was quick to condemn the terrorists.
senses.lear_examp: At first these needs were satisfied by different religions, but as we are living in a material world that does not care about spiritual things any more, we created our own idols whom we can look at, judge, admire or condemn - celebrities.

senses.sense: about
senses.dict_examp: I got a letter from the state tax department concerning the new commuter tax.
senses.lear_examp: I am writing in reply to your letter concerning the prize I won in your competition, which is two weeks at Camp California in the U.S.A.

senses.sense: a performance of music by one or more musicians or singers
senses.dict_examp: a pop/classical concert
senses.lear_examp: To help with the concert I can sell tickets.

senses.sense: to think very carefully about something you are doing and nothing else
senses.dict_examp: Come on, concentrate! We haven't got all day to do this.
senses.lear_examp: I can't concentrate on studying.

senses.sense: to be present in large numbers or amounts in a particular area
senses.dict_examp: Most of the fighting was concentrated in the mountains.
senses.lear_examp: However it might imply a shift from large stores, concentrated in a few areas within or outside the city, to more local services.

senses.sense: If something is compulsory, you must do it because of a rule or law.
senses.dict_examp: Wearing seat belts in cars is compulsory by law.
senses.lear_examp: We have asked participants to wear a typical traditional dress/suit from their country - of course, this is not compulsory but everyone is warmly invited to do so.

senses.sense: to admit that something is true, even though you do not want to
senses.dict_examp: Even the company chairman concedes that the results are disappointing.
senses.lear_examp: As a frequent user of the town library, I had to concede that the article was telling the truth.

senses.sense: to allow someone to have something, even though you do not want to
senses.dict_examp: The government will not concede to rebel demands.
senses.lear_examp: "It's wonderful, isn't it, how you always get what you pray for." This quote, Milly's reaction when her father concedes to buying her a horse, is a good illustration of her general attitude towards religion and life.

senses.sense: worried
senses.dict_examp: He's very concerned about her health.
senses.lear_examp: We are getting more and more concerned about our health and how to get and keep fit nowadays.

senses.sense: used to say what someone's opinion is
senses.dict_examp: As far as I'm concerned, feng shui is just nonsense.
senses.lear_examp: As far as Laura was concerned, he was the most disgusting man in the world.

senses.sense: used to say what you are talking about
senses.dict_examp: As far as money is concerned, we're doing very well.
senses.lear_examp: First of all, I think the Majestic Hotel would be the right location, but I have doubts as far as the costs are concerned.

senses.sense: to be about a particular subject
senses.dict_examp: The program was more concerned with politics than the history of the place.
senses.lear_examp: This report is concerned with finding the best accommodation for the three-day trip in north-west England.

senses.sense: involved in something or affected by it
senses.dict_examp: A letter will be sent out to everyone concerned.
senses.lear_examp: The amount of refund is to be negotiated with everyone concerned separately.

senses.sense: to hide something
senses.dict_examp: The listening device was concealed in a pen.
senses.lear_examp: She had managed to conceal her dark secret from everybody.

senses.sense: with confidence or in a confident way
senses.dict_examp: Try to act confidently, even if you feel nervous.
senses.lear_examp: I am quite a hard worker and I can confidently say that I am quite a reliable person.

senses.sense: when you are certain of your ability to do things well
senses.dict_examp: He's got the confidence to walk into a room of strangers and immediately start a conversation.
senses.lear_examp: As a result of such a bad appearance he lacks confidence.

senses.sense: trusting someone's ability or believing that something will produce good results
senses.dict_examp: Kate's new to the job, but I've got every confidence in her.
senses.lear_examp: I have every confidence in your ability to reach a compromise.

senses.sense: If you tell something to someone in confidence, you do not want them to tell anyone else.
senses.dict_examp: I'm sorry, she told me that in confidence.
senses.lear_examp: His real name isn't Piggy but he told Ralph in confidence that they called him that in school because of his appearance.

senses.sense: to prevent someone from leaving a place or to prevent something from spreading
senses.dict_examp: He was confined to a prison cell for several days.
senses.lear_examp: Being Portuguese, I was confined to this small rectangle until I was a 15-year-old boy.

senses.sense: to make an arrangement or meeting certain, often by telephone or in writing
senses.dict_examp: Six people have confirmed that they will be attending and ten haven't replied yet.
senses.lear_examp: I just want to confirm that we're going to the ABC cinema tonight.

senses.sense: to say or show that something is true
senses.dict_examp: His wife confirmed that he had left the house that morning.
senses.lear_examp: Besides, it was confirmed by scientists that consumerism may develop into a compulsion.

senses.sense: secret, especially in an official situation
senses.dict_examp: These documents are strictly confidential.
senses.lear_examp: Remember, you are under no obligation to do anything and of course we will treat the confidential information you give us with discretion and respect.

senses.sense: when people do not understand what is happening, what they should do or who someone or something is
senses.dict_examp: There seems to be some confusion about/over who is actually giving the talk.
senses.lear_examp: This caused some confusion because the courses were not completely prepared.

senses.sense: a situation, often with a lot of activity and noise, in which people do not know what to do
senses.dict_examp: In the confusion after the bomb blast, I lost my bag.
senses.lear_examp: In the confusion someone pushed her against the wall and she hurt her shoulder.

senses.sense: a feeling of not being able to think clearly
senses.dict_examp: He could see the confusion on Marion's face.
senses.lear_examp: Then I thought he recognized my confusion; therefore, he opened the box, picking up something from it.

senses.sense: something that joins things together
senses.dict_examp: Many companies now offer free connection to the Internet.
senses.lear_examp: Moreover, some portable phones have a connection to the web, so it is easy to read newspapers if one hasn't enough money to buy them.

senses.sense: when someone or something is involved with or related to someone or something else
senses.dict_examp: The connection between smoking and heart disease is well known.
senses.lear_examp: If you are aware of the connection between food and health you can start changing your eating habits.

senses.sense: used to say what something is about
senses.dict_examp: I am writing in connection with the above job advertised in The Daily Press on Monday 12th February.
senses.lear_examp: Dear Mrs Brown, I am writing in connection with a surprise birthday party for your husband, Mr Brown.

senses.sense: a train, bus or aircraft that leaves a short time after another arrives, so people can continue their journey
senses.dict_examp: The train was half an hour late and I missed my connection.
senses.lear_examp: Because of bad bus connections it's not easy to get there.

senses.sense: the part of you that makes you feel guilty when you have behaved badly
senses.dict_examp: a guilty conscience
senses.lear_examp: Young people have pangs of conscience and are invariably hit by pestering anxiety but they adamantly refuse to admit it.

senses.sense: a large, formal meeting, often lasting a few days, where people discuss their work, politics, subjects they are studying, etc.
senses.dict_examp: a conference on women's rights
senses.lear_examp: As you know, I went to Canada in order to take part in an environmental conference.

senses.sense: always doing your work with a lot of care
senses.dict_examp: a conscientious student
senses.lear_examp: She is conscientious and hardworking.

senses.sense: Consecutive events, numbers, or periods of time come one after the other.
senses.dict_examp: the third consecutive day of rain
senses.lear_examp: Complaints from students have been increasing for the second consecutive year, tape players are repeatedly reported not functioning.

senses.sense: certain about your ability to do things well
senses.dict_examp: Be a bit more confident in yourself!
senses.lear_examp: But I soon felt more confident, as I saw what activities they were doing: some people were playing tennis, others were sunbathing in the garden.

senses.sense: being certain that something will happen
senses.dict_examp: Are you confident that enough people will attend the event?
senses.lear_examp: All in all, I'm confident that a solution will be found and our town will soon regain its former attractive look.

senses.sense: to make someone unable to think clearly, or to make something difficult to understand
senses.dict_examp: You're confusing him! Tell him slowly and one thing at a time.
senses.lear_examp: When the corpse was found he - successfully - tried to confuse Mrs. Marple, Scotland Yard and the members of the family where he was the doctor.

senses.sense: to think that one person or thing is another person or thing
senses.dict_examp: I think you're confusing me with my sister - we look quite similar.
senses.lear_examp: I had confused the two words, "uvas", which means grapes, and "huevos", which means eggs and said "huevas", which unfortunately means testicles, instead...

senses.sense: unable to think clearly or to understand something
senses.dict_examp: People keep telling me different things and I'm getting very confused.
senses.lear_examp: At first I felt very confused.

senses.sense: not clear
senses.dict_examp: The witnesses gave confused accounts of what happened.
senses.lear_examp: What can a child think, hearing such confused explanations about animals that don't live where they should live, that don't live how they should live.

senses.sense: something that you say when you want to congratulate someone
senses.dict_examp: "I passed my driving test yesterday." "Congratulations! That's fantastic."
senses.lear_examp: Congratulations on your wedding.

senses.sense: someone who stands in front of a group of musicians or singers and controls their performance
senses.dict_examp: a famous conductor
senses.lear_examp: I am fifty five years old and have experience as a conductor of a choir.

senses.sense: to tell someone something, or show them something to try to make them admit they have done something wrong
senses.dict_examp: Confronted with the evidence, she broke down and confessed.
senses.lear_examp: We had bills coming in our door, old ones which weren't paid and whenever I confronted him, he told me he would take care of it.

senses.sense: to be in a difficult situation, or to be shown something which may cause difficulties
senses.dict_examp: We are confronted by the possibility of war.
senses.lear_examp: Youngsters are confronted with a lot of difficulties and dangers and are often bound to collapse psychologically from the hard pressure on them.

senses.sense: to see that a problem exists and try to deal with it
senses.dict_examp: First, they must confront their feelings of anger.
senses.lear_examp: His inability to confront Ethan's death, as well as his being too methodical, causes his wife Sarah to reconsider their marriage.

senses.sense: when someone is awake and can think and notice things
senses.dict_examp: He lost consciousness for several minutes.
senses.lear_examp: He lost consciousness and lay there on the floor just in front of me.

senses.sense: when someone knows about something
senses.dict_examp: There's a growing consciousness about environmental issues among young people.
senses.lear_examp: It also springs up out of a pleasure of playing the game and a consciousness that their health matters and being fit is an important element of it.

senses.sense: to join or be joined with something else
senses.dict_examp: Can I connect my printer to your computer?
senses.lear_examp: I want to buy a computer to play games and connect to the Internet as well as listen to music in my free time.

senses.sense: to see or show that two or more people or things are involved with each other
senses.dict_examp: There is no evidence to connect him with the crime.
senses.lear_examp: Happiness should not be defined as material access, it should be connected with one of the most basic human needs, love.

senses.sense: to admit that you have done something wrong or something that you feel guilty or bad about
senses.dict_examp: She confessed to her husband that she had sold her wedding ring.
senses.lear_examp: I must confess I've put on four kilos in the last three months and the bicycle will help me to become fitter.

senses.sense: serious disagreement between people with opposing opinions or principles
senses.dict_examp: There was a lot of conflict between the two parties.
senses.lear_examp: As you know I was in conflict with myself, should I buy a computer or a bicycle?

senses.sense: fighting between two or more groups of people or countries
senses.dict_examp: armed conflict
senses.lear_examp: In these years, Europe was in conflict with China, which meant war.

senses.sense: a situation where someone cannot make fair decisions because they are influenced by something
senses.dict_examp: She resigned from the committee because of a conflict of interest.
senses.lear_examp: It could become a conflict of interest, but he never lets it.

senses.sense: difficult to understand
senses.dict_examp: I found the instructions very confusing.
senses.lear_examp: As a secret agent I was prepared for this sort of thing but it was surprising and confusing.

senses.sense: a word such as 'and', 'but', 'while' or 'although' that connects words, phrases and clauses in a sentence
working, used, or happening with something or someone else
senses.dict_examp: Our librarians use their knowledge in conjunction with the computer network.
senses.lear_examp: Therefore if the banning of private cars takes place in conjunction with development in the public transportation system in that city, this whole development will have more advantages despite some slight difficulties at the start.

senses.sense: to know that something is present or that something is happening
senses.dict_examp: The tooth doesn't exactly hurt, but I'm conscious of it all the time.
senses.lear_examp: We have to be conscious that we are destroying the world where we are living.

senses.sense: awake and able to think and notice things
senses.dict_examp: He's still conscious but he's very badly injured.

senses.sense: a decision/choice/effort, etc. that you make intentionally
senses.dict_examp: Did you make a conscious decision to lose weight?
senses.lear_examp: The fairly recent possibilities of birth control allow you to make a conscious decision about having children and you can postpone that decision until well after 30.

senses.sense: when something is full or blocked
senses.dict_examp: There is always traffic congestion on this highway.
senses.lear_examp: The traffic congestion in Belo Horizonte is an issue that can't be ignored.

senses.sense: to take control of a country or to defeat people by war
senses.dict_examp: The English were conquered by the Normans  in 1066.
senses.lear_examp: However, following imperialistic politics, the Persian King Darios wanted to expand his Kingdom in Europe, so he had to conquer Greece.

senses.sense: a fight or argument
senses.dict_examp: She witnessed a confrontation between the two men.
senses.lear_examp: There, he finds himself in a direct confrontation with Captain Beatty, the head of the fire station, who represents everything that's evil, as he knows about books but still willingly destroys them.

senses.sense: when you admit that you have done something wrong or illegal
senses.dict_examp: He made a full confession to the police.
senses.lear_examp: I also have a confession to make.

senses.sense: a statement, often written, that an arrangement or meeting is certain
senses.dict_examp: a letter of confirmation
senses.lear_examp: I look forward to receiving your confirmation.

senses.sense: to tell someone that you are happy because they have done something good or something good has happened to them
senses.dict_examp: I was just congratulating Ceri on winning her race.
senses.lear_examp: Needless to say, everybody congratulated her and she spent all evening answering questions such as: "Why did you choose water jumping?" or "Isn't it difficult for a teenager to train five hours a day and to study?"

senses.sense: relating to the constitution of a country
senses.dict_examp: a constitutional crisis
senses.lear_examp: Acting likewise, not only will a generation of co-dependent individuals run this country, but also devalue some constitutional principles and even jeopardize democratic institutions already established.

senses.sense: when you discuss something with someone in order to get their advice or opinion about it
senses.dict_examp: After consultation with his lawyers, he decided to abandon the case.
senses.lear_examp: After full consideration and consultation of the three groups of people mentioned above, we come to the result that charity workers should have the opportunity to present the work they are doing on TV.

senses.sense: a meeting to discuss something or to get advice
senses.dict_examp: a medical consultation
senses.lear_examp: We also plan to employ 2 graduate students from the psychology department in giving free consultations to the children to help them cope with their concerns and worries.

senses.sense: to build something from several parts
senses.dict_examp: The building was constructed in 1930.
senses.lear_examp: Using some wood, we constructed small seats and tables.

senses.sense: large or important enough to be noticed
senses.dict_examp: It's a considerable sum of money.
senses.lear_examp: I have considerable experience as a worker on a farm, having worked on my father's farm from 1956 to 1986.

senses.sense: to go to a particular person or book to get information or advice
senses.dict_examp: For more information, consult your travel agent.
senses.lear_examp: Even if I think I know what to write, I usually consult an interpreter and/or a lawyer.

senses.sense: to discuss something with someone before you make a decision
senses.dict_examp: Why didn't you consult me about this?
senses.lear_examp: As it is just after Christmas I had to consult my wife - that is why it took some time to write this reply.

senses.sense: to eat or drink something
senses.dict_examp: People generally consume far too much sugar.
senses.lear_examp: People who eat fresh vegetables and meat tend to have good digestion and tend to consume less salt.

senses.sense: to use fuel, energy or time, especially in large amounts
senses.dict_examp: Our high living standards cause our present population to consume 25 percent of the world's oil.
senses.lear_examp: It did consume a lot of time, but it was very rewarding.

senses.sense: to have so much of a feeling that it affects everything you do

senses.sense: to control something by limiting it

senses.sense: helpful or useful

senses.sense: the work of building something, especially houses, offices, bridges, etc.

senses.sense: something that is built

senses.sense: The construction of a sentence or phrase is the way the words are arranged.

senses.sense: in a way that does not change, often a positive way

senses.sense: used for saying that something is true in general if you think about all its aspects

senses.sense: to be made of or formed from something

senses.sense: when you are careful not to waste energy, water, etc.

senses.sense: all the time or often

senses.sense: not trusting sudden changes or new ideas

senses.sense: staying at the same level

senses.sense: as a result

senses.sense: something that limits what you can do

senses.sense: when you think about something very carefully

senses.sense: something that you have to think about when you make decisions or plans

senses.sense: when you are kind to people or think about their feelings

senses.sense: showing concern for other people and their feelings

senses.sense: always behaving or happening in a similar, usually positive, way

senses.sense: pleased with your situation and not hoping for change or improvement

senses.sense: to have so much of a feeling that it affects everything you do

senses.sense: used to show that the opposite of what has just been said is true

senses.sense: used to show that the opposite of what has just been said is true

senses.sense: saying or showing the opposite

senses.sense: opposite to what someone said or thought

senses.sense: opposite or very different

senses.lear_examp: It took them a week to conclude that, apparently, and as long as nobody came out with a contrary theory to theirs, they were right.

senses.sense: the quality of being convenient

senses.sense: to remove something or form a shape by cutting, usually something made of paper or cloth
senses.dict_examp: She cut out his picture from the magazine.
senses.lear_examp: To make it cheaper, cut the coupons out of the papers, don't go shopping when you're hungry and try to stick to your budget.

senses.sense: to stop eating or drinking something, usually to improve your health
senses.dict_examp: I've cut out red meat from my diet.
senses.lear_examp: I think they should also try to cut out cigarettes and take some exercise besides changing their eating habits.

senses.sense: to not have the right qualities for something
senses.dict_examp: I'm not really cut out to be a nurse.
senses.lear_examp: I still think her behavior was absolutely beastly, because students will always make mistakes but it is vital not to reprimand them too harshly otherwise they will lose all their confidence and become convinced that they are not cut out for school.

senses.sense: to cut something into pieces
senses.dict_examp: Could you cut up the cake and put it on plates?
senses.lear_examp: I cut up the cake.

senses.sense: an injury made when the skin is cut with something sharp
senses.dict_examp: He suffered cuts and bruises in the accident.
senses.lear_examp: I have got a broken knee, but apart from that and a few cuts and bruises, I'm all right.

senses.sense: a reduction in the number or amount of something
senses.dict_examp: tax/job cuts
senses.lear_examp: Unfortunately, due to government spending cuts he has lost his employment.

senses.sense: the feeling of wanting to know or learn about something
senses.dict_examp: My curiosity got the better of me and I opened the envelope.
senses.lear_examp: When the warrior had left, he explored the cave out of curiosity and to his big surprise he found the treasure.

senses.sense: the money that is used in a particular country at a particular time
senses.dict_examp: foreign currency
senses.lear_examp: Take local currency in case you want to buy something.

senses.sense: a small round container, often with a handle, used for drinking tea, coffee, etc.
senses.dict_examp: a cup of coffee/tea
senses.lear_examp: I'd like to drink a cup of tea.

senses.sense: a specially designed cup, usually with two handles and often made of silver, which is given as a prize in a sports competition, or a game or match in which the winner receives such a cup
senses.dict_examp: Anna won this cup in the school squash championship.
senses.lear_examp: This weekend we worked hard to win the tennis cup.

senses.sense: believing that people are only interested in themselves and are not sincere
senses.dict_examp: Many people have become cynical about politicians.
senses.lear_examp: Consequently, we had better not jump to such cynical conclusions and enjoy the competition.

senses.sense: very modern and with all the newest developments
senses.dict_examp: cutting-edge design/technology
senses.lear_examp: On the other hand, in the past our previous generation could not enjoy such cutting-edge technology as it was not developed well before 1970.

senses.sense: a document which describes your education, qualifications and the jobs you have done, which you send to an employer that you want to work for
senses.dict_examp: Send me your CV.
senses.lear_examp: These students are the same as me, they want to pass their exams next year and put the degree on their CV.

senses.sense: to use  a knife or other sharp tool to divide something, remove part of something, or make a hole in something
senses.dict_examp: She cut herself a slice of bread.
senses.lear_examp: I cut the cake with my friends.

senses.sense: to injure yourself on a sharp object which makes you bleed
senses.dict_examp: She cut her finger on some broken glass.
senses.lear_examp: The robot had cut its hand.

senses.sense: to reduce the size or amount of something
senses.dict_examp: cut prices/costs
senses.lear_examp: The third thing is Internet business. This way is very good for both consumer and company, to cut the cost.

senses.sense: to remove part of a film or piece of writing
senses.dict_examp: Several scenes had been cut when the movie was shown on TV.
senses.lear_examp: You'll see how the film is cut to fit the story into two hours, more or less.

senses.sense: to go from one side of an area to the other, instead of going around it
senses.dict_examp: If we cut across this field, it will save time.
senses.lear_examp: I wanted to cut across the garden of the house, and climbed over the fence.

senses.sense: If a problem or subject cuts across different groups of people, all of those groups are affected by it or interested in it.
senses.dict_examp: Interest in the Internet cuts across all age groups.
senses.lear_examp: The TV has a wide audience cutting across all the sections of the society.

senses.sense: to reduce the amount of money being spent on something
senses.dict_examp: We have had to cut back on training this year.
senses.lear_examp: There are ways to cut back on spending.

senses.sense: If you cut down a tree or bush, you make it fall to the ground by cutting it near the bottom.
senses.dict_examp: The new owners cut down the apple trees.
senses.lear_examp: People cut down the tropical rainforest to get the wood and make room for agriculture.

senses.sense: to reduce the amount, number, length or size of something
senses.dict_examp: They've cut her hours down at work.
senses.lear_examp: You'll see that this will help you to cut down your overtime in the long run.

senses.sense: to eat or drink less of a particular thing, usually in order to improve your health
senses.dict_examp: I'm trying to cut down on the amount of sugar I eat.
senses.lear_examp: Secondly you must quit smoking and you must cut down on coffee.

senses.sense: to stop providing something such as electricity or water
senses.dict_examp: If we don't pay the gas bill, we'll be cut off.
senses.lear_examp: That's when the electricity was cut off.

senses.sense: to prevent people from reaching or leaving a place, or to separate them from other people
senses.dict_examp: The whole village was cut off by flooding.
senses.lear_examp: We were isolated from the other nearby villages because the snow cut off the only road to our village.

senses.dict_examp: She cut out his picture from the magazine.
senses.lear_examp: To make it cheaper, cut the coupons out of the papers, don't go shopping when you're hungry and try to stick to your budget.

senses.dict_examp: I've cut out red meat from my diet.
senses.lear_examp: I think they should also try to cut out cigarettes and take some exercise besides changing their eating habits.

senses.dict_examp: I'm not really cut out to be a nurse.
senses.lear_examp: I still think her behavior was absolutely beastly, because students will always make mistakes but it is vital not to reprimand them too harshly otherwise they will lose all their confidence and become convinced that they are not cut out for school.

senses.sense: to cut something into pieces
senses.dict_examp: Could you cut up the cake and put it on plates?
senses.lear_examp: I cut up the cake.

senses.sense: an injury made when the skin is cut with something sharp
senses.dict_examp: He suffered cuts and bruises in the accident.
senses.lear_examp: I have got a broken knee, but apart from that and a few cuts and bruises, I'm all right.

senses.sense: a reduction in the number or amount of something
senses.dict_examp: tax/job cuts
senses.lear_examp: Unfortunately, due to government spending cuts he has lost his employment.

senses.sense: the sport or activity of riding a bicycle
senses.dict_examp: professional cycling
senses.lear_examp: I want to go swimming and cycling.

senses.sense: someone who rides a bike
senses.dict_examp: He drove into a cyclist.
senses.lear_examp: There was me, my friend and a group of ten people guided by a professional cyclist.

senses.sense: a series of events which happen in a particular order and are often repeated
senses.dict_examp: the life cycle of a moth
senses.lear_examp: So, the main disadvantage of zoos is that they put animals away from something which belongs to the natural cycle of life.

senses.sense: a bicycle
senses.dict_examp: a cycle route/ride
senses.lear_examp: I am writing about our cycle routes.

senses.sense: to ride a bicycle
senses.dict_examp: I usually walk or cycle to work.
senses.lear_examp: We cycled around Hungary.

senses.sense: a reduction of something, usually to save money
senses.dict_examp: The company has made cutbacks and closed one of its factories.
senses.lear_examp: There have been enormous cutbacks in the budget and children and teenagers are the ones who have suffered the most.
